bibl.title: Letter from R.H. Brooke to Philip Showalter Hench, August 29, 1941

div1.p: Brooke informs Hench that the records he has requested are warehoused, and that Brooke will examine them as soon as he is able.

div1.head: Letter from R.H. Brooke to Philip Showalter Hench, August 29, 1941
div1.opener:
IN REPLY REFER TO S.G.O. 201 (Hench, P. S.)
rhb-gtr
WAR DEPARTMENT
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL
WASHINGTON
August 29, 1941.
Dr. P. S. Hench,
Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minnesota.
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Reference is made to your letter of July 10, 1941, and a
tracer dated August 21, 1941. I very much regret the delay in
replying to these letters which was occasioned by my absence
from the Department on a well-earned leave of absence.

The old records which you desire are stored in the Quarter-
master's warehouse at Fort Myer, Virginia, and in order to make
additional space for the use of the Quartermaster Department it
has become necessary to condense these records by double and
triple stacking them. These records are not available at this
time for search for the papers that you are interested in. As
soon as the files are in shape for making a search I will arrange
to make the search myself and will notify you as to the amount of
correspondence which you requested be microfilmed by The Surgeon
General's Library.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, R. H. Brooke,
Chief Clerk. ALL COMMUNICATIONS SHOULD BE ADDRESSED TO “THE SURGEON GENERAL U. S. ARMY, WASHINGTON, D.C.”
